94 def doc_note(initialdoc, note):
95  """
96  Adds a Notes section to an existing docstring.
97 
98  """
99  if initialdoc is None:
100  return
101  if note is None:
102  return initialdoc
103  newdoc = """
104  %s
105 
106  Notes
107  -----
108  %s
109  """
110  return newdoc % (initialdoc, note)

113 def get_object_signature(obj):
114  """
115  Get the signature from obj
116 
117  """
118  try:
119  sig = formatargspec(*getargspec(obj))
120  except TypeError:
121  sig = ''
122  return sig

146 ###############################################################################
147 # Filling options #
148 ###############################################################################

150 
151 # b: boolean - c: complex - f: floats - i: integer - O: object - S: string
152 default_filler = {'b': True,
153  'c': 1.e20 + 0.0j,
154  'f': 1.e20,
155  'i': 999999,
156  'O': '?',
157  'S': b'N/A',
158  'u': 999999,
159  'V': '???',
160  'U': sixu('N/A')
161  }
162 
163 # Add datetime64 and timedelta64 types
164 for v in ["Y", "M", "W", "D", "h", "m", "s", "ms", "us", "ns", "ps",
165  "fs", "as"]:
166  default_filler["M8[" + v + "]"] = np.datetime64("NaT", v)
167  default_filler["m8[" + v + "]"] = np.timedelta64("NaT", v)
168 
169 max_filler = ntypes._minvals
170 max_filler.update([(k, -np.inf) for k in [np.float32, np.float64]])
171 min_filler = ntypes._maxvals
172 min_filler.update([(k, +np.inf) for k in [np.float32, np.float64]])
173 if 'float128' in ntypes.typeDict:
174  max_filler.update([(np.float128, -np.inf)])
175  min_filler.update([(np.float128, +np.inf)])

177 
178 def default_fill_value(obj):
179  """
180  Return the default fill value for the argument object.
181 
182  The default filling value depends on the datatype of the input
183  array or the type of the input scalar:
184 
185  ======== ========
186  datatype default
187  ======== ========
188  bool True
189  int 999999
190  float 1.e20
191  complex 1.e20+0j
192  object '?'
193  string 'N/A'
194  ======== ========
195 
196 
197  Parameters
198  ----------
199  obj : ndarray, dtype or scalar
200  The array data-type or scalar for which the default fill value
201  is returned.
202 
203  Returns
204  -------
205  fill_value : scalar
206  The default fill value.
207 
208  Examples
209  --------
210  >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(1)
211  999999
212  >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(np.array([1.1, 2., np.pi]))
213  1e+20
214  >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(np.dtype(complex))
215  (1e+20+0j)
216 
217  """
218  if hasattr(obj, 'dtype'):
219  defval = _check_fill_value(None, obj.dtype)
220  elif isinstance(obj, np.dtype):
221  if obj.subdtype:
222  defval = default_filler.get(obj.subdtype[0].kind, '?')
223  elif obj.kind in 'Mm':
224  defval = default_filler.get(obj.str[1:], '?')
225  else:
226  defval = default_filler.get(obj.kind, '?')
227  elif isinstance(obj, float):
228  defval = default_filler['f']
229  elif isinstance(obj, int) or isinstance(obj, long):
230  defval = default_filler['i']
231  elif isinstance(obj, bytes):
232  defval = default_filler['S']
233  elif isinstance(obj, unicode):
234  defval = default_filler['U']
235  elif isinstance(obj, complex):
236  defval = default_filler['c']
237  else:
238  defval = default_filler['O']
239  return defval
240 
241 
242 def _recursive_extremum_fill_value(ndtype, extremum):
243  names = ndtype.names
244  if names:
245  deflist = []
246  for name in names:
247  fval = _recursive_extremum_fill_value(ndtype[name], extremum)
248  deflist.append(fval)
249  return tuple(deflist)
250  return extremum[ndtype]

252 
253 def minimum_fill_value(obj):
254  """
255  Return the maximum value that can be represented by the dtype of an object.
256 
257  This function is useful for calculating a fill value suitable for
258  taking the minimum of an array with a given dtype.
259 
260  Parameters
261  ----------
262  obj : ndarray or dtype
263  An object that can be queried for it's numeric type.
264 
265  Returns
266  -------
267  val : scalar
268  The maximum representable value.
269 
270  Raises
271  ------
272  TypeError
273  If `obj` isn't a suitable numeric type.
274 
275  See Also
276  --------
277  maximum_fill_value : The inverse function.
278  set_fill_value : Set the filling value of a masked array.
279  MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value.
280 
281  Examples
282  --------
283  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
284  >>> a = np.int8()
285  >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a)
286  127
287  >>> a = np.int32()
288  >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a)
289  2147483647
290 
291  An array of numeric data can also be passed.
292 
293  >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.int8)
294  >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a)
295  127
296  >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.float32)
297  >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a)
298  inf
299 
300  """
301  errmsg = "Unsuitable type for calculating minimum."
302  if hasattr(obj, 'dtype'):
303  return _recursive_extremum_fill_value(obj.dtype, min_filler)
304  elif isinstance(obj, float):
305  return min_filler[ntypes.typeDict['float_']]
306  elif isinstance(obj, int):
307  return min_filler[ntypes.typeDict['int_']]
308  elif isinstance(obj, long):
309  return min_filler[ntypes.typeDict['uint']]
310  elif isinstance(obj, np.dtype):
311  return min_filler[obj]
312  else:
313  raise TypeError(errmsg)
314

316 def maximum_fill_value(obj):
317  """
318  Return the minimum value that can be represented by the dtype of an object.
319 
320  This function is useful for calculating a fill value suitable for
321  taking the maximum of an array with a given dtype.
322 
323  Parameters
324  ----------
325  obj : {ndarray, dtype}
326  An object that can be queried for it's numeric type.
327 
328  Returns
329  -------
330  val : scalar
331  The minimum representable value.
332 
333  Raises
334  ------
335  TypeError
336  If `obj` isn't a suitable numeric type.
337 
338  See Also
339  --------
340  minimum_fill_value : The inverse function.
341  set_fill_value : Set the filling value of a masked array.
342  MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value.
343 
344  Examples
345  --------
346  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
347  >>> a = np.int8()
348  >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a)
349  -128
350  >>> a = np.int32()
351  >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a)
352  -2147483648
353 
354  An array of numeric data can also be passed.
355 
356  >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.int8)
357  >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a)
358  -128
359  >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.float32)
360  >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a)
361  -inf
362 
363  """
364  errmsg = "Unsuitable type for calculating maximum."
365  if hasattr(obj, 'dtype'):
366  return _recursive_extremum_fill_value(obj.dtype, max_filler)
367  elif isinstance(obj, float):
368  return max_filler[ntypes.typeDict['float_']]
369  elif isinstance(obj, int):
370  return max_filler[ntypes.typeDict['int_']]
371  elif isinstance(obj, long):
372  return max_filler[ntypes.typeDict['uint']]
373  elif isinstance(obj, np.dtype):
374  return max_filler[obj]
375  else:
376  raise TypeError(errmsg)

378 
379 def _recursive_set_default_fill_value(dt):
380  """
381  Create the default fill value for a structured dtype.
382 
383  Parameters
384  ----------
385  dt: dtype
386  The structured dtype for which to create the fill value.
387 
388  Returns
389  -------
390  val: tuple
391  A tuple of values corresponding to the default structured fill value.
392 
393  """
394  deflist = []
395  for name in dt.names:
396  currenttype = dt[name]
397  if currenttype.subdtype:
398  currenttype = currenttype.subdtype[0]
399 
400  if currenttype.names:
401  deflist.append(
402  tuple(_recursive_set_default_fill_value(currenttype)))
403  else:
404  deflist.append(default_fill_value(currenttype))
405  return tuple(deflist)
406 
407 
408 def _recursive_set_fill_value(fillvalue, dt):
409  """
410  Create a fill value for a structured dtype.
411 
412  Parameters
413  ----------
414  fillvalue: scalar or array_like
415  Scalar or array representing the fill value. If it is of shorter
416  length than the number of fields in dt, it will be resized.
417  dt: dtype
418  The structured dtype for which to create the fill value.
419 
420  Returns
421  -------
422  val: tuple
423  A tuple of values corresponding to the structured fill value.
424 
425  """
426  fillvalue = np.resize(fillvalue, len(dt.names))
427  output_value = []
428  for (fval, name) in zip(fillvalue, dt.names):
429  cdtype = dt[name]
430  if cdtype.subdtype:
431  cdtype = cdtype.subdtype[0]
432 
433  if cdtype.names:
434  output_value.append(tuple(_recursive_set_fill_value(fval, cdtype)))
435  else:
436  output_value.append(np.array(fval, dtype=cdtype).item())
437  return tuple(output_value)
438 
439 
440 def _check_fill_value(fill_value, ndtype):
441  """
442  Private function validating the given `fill_value` for the given dtype.
443 
444  If fill_value is None, it is set to the default corresponding to the dtype
445  if this latter is standard (no fields). If the datatype is flexible (named
446  fields), fill_value is set to a tuple whose elements are the default fill
447  values corresponding to each field.
448 
449  If fill_value is not None, its value is forced to the given dtype.
450 
451  """
452  ndtype = np.dtype(ndtype)
453  fields = ndtype.fields
454  if fill_value is None:
455  if fields:
456  fill_value = np.array(_recursive_set_default_fill_value(ndtype),
457  dtype=ndtype)
458  else:
459  fill_value = default_fill_value(ndtype)
460  elif fields:
461  fdtype = [(_[0], _[1]) for _ in ndtype.descr]
462  if isinstance(fill_value, (ndarray, np.void)):
463  try:
464  fill_value = np.array(fill_value, copy=False, dtype=fdtype)
465  except ValueError:
466  err_msg = "Unable to transform %s to dtype %s"
467  raise ValueError(err_msg % (fill_value, fdtype))
468  else:
469  fill_value = np.asarray(fill_value, dtype=object)
470  fill_value = np.array(_recursive_set_fill_value(fill_value, ndtype),
471  dtype=ndtype)
472  else:
473  if isinstance(fill_value, basestring) and (ndtype.char not in 'OSVU'):
474  err_msg = "Cannot set fill value of string with array of dtype %s"
475  raise TypeError(err_msg % ndtype)
476  else:
477  # In case we want to convert 1e20 to int.
478  try:
479  fill_value = np.array(fill_value, copy=False, dtype=ndtype)
480  except OverflowError:
481  # Raise TypeError instead of OverflowError. OverflowError
482  # is seldom used, and the real problem here is that the
483  # passed fill_value is not compatible with the ndtype.
484  err_msg = "Fill value %s overflows dtype %s"
485  raise TypeError(err_msg % (fill_value, ndtype))
486  return np.array(fill_value)
487 
488 
489 def set_fill_value(a, fill_value):
490  """
491  Set the filling value of a, if a is a masked array.
492 
493  This function changes the fill value of the masked array `a` in place.
494  If `a` is not a masked array, the function returns silently, without
495  doing anything.
496 
497  Parameters
498  ----------
499  a : array_like
500  Input array.
501  fill_value : dtype
502  Filling value. A consistency test is performed to make sure
503  the value is compatible with the dtype of `a`.
504 
505  Returns
506  -------
507  None
508  Nothing returned by this function.
509 
510  See Also
511  --------
512  maximum_fill_value : Return the default fill value for a dtype.
513  MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value.
514  MaskedArray.set_fill_value : Equivalent method.
515 
516  Examples
517  --------
518  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
519  >>> a = np.arange(5)
520  >>> a
521  array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4])
522  >>> a = ma.masked_where(a < 3, a)
523  >>> a
524  masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3 4],
525  mask = [ True True True False False],
526  fill_value=999999)
527  >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, -999)
528  >>> a
529  masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3 4],
530  mask = [ True True True False False],
531  fill_value=-999)
532 
533  Nothing happens if `a` is not a masked array.
534 
535  >>> a = range(5)
536  >>> a
537  [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
538  >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, 100)
539  >>> a
540  [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
541  >>> a = np.arange(5)
542  >>> a
543  array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4])
544  >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, 100)
545  >>> a
546  array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4])
547 
548  """
549  if isinstance(a, MaskedArray):
550  a.set_fill_value(fill_value)
551  return
552 
553 
554 def get_fill_value(a):
555  """
556  Return the filling value of a, if any. Otherwise, returns the
557  default filling value for that type.
558 
559  """
560  if isinstance(a, MaskedArray):
561  result = a.fill_value
562  else:
563  result = default_fill_value(a)
564  return result

566 
567 def common_fill_value(a, b):
568  """
569  Return the common filling value of two masked arrays, if any.
570 
571  If ``a.fill_value == b.fill_value``, return the fill value,
572  otherwise return None.
573 
574  Parameters
575  ----------
576  a, b : MaskedArray
577  The masked arrays for which to compare fill values.
578 
579  Returns
580  -------
581  fill_value : scalar or None
582  The common fill value, or None.
583 
584  Examples
585  --------
586  >>> x = np.ma.array([0, 1.], fill_value=3)
587  >>> y = np.ma.array([0, 1.], fill_value=3)
588  >>> np.ma.common_fill_value(x, y)
589  3.0
590 
591  """
592  t1 = get_fill_value(a)
593  t2 = get_fill_value(b)
594  if t1 == t2:
595  return t1
596  return None

598 
599 def filled(a, fill_value=None):
600  """
601  Return input as an array with masked data replaced by a fill value.
602 
603  If `a` is not a `MaskedArray`, `a` itself is returned.
604  If `a` is a `MaskedArray` and `fill_value` is None, `fill_value` is set to
605  ``a.fill_value``.
606 
607  Parameters
608  ----------
609  a : MaskedArray or array_like
610  An input object.
611  fill_value : scalar, optional
612  Filling value. Default is None.
613 
614  Returns
615  -------
616  a : ndarray
617  The filled array.
618 
619  See Also
620  --------
621  compressed
622 
623  Examples
624  --------
625  >>> x = np.ma.array(np.arange(9).reshape(3, 3), mask=[[1, 0, 0],
626  ... [1, 0, 0],
627  ... [0, 0, 0]])
628  >>> x.filled()
629  array([[999999, 1, 2],
630  [999999, 4, 5],
631  [ 6, 7, 8]])
632 
633  """
634  if hasattr(a, 'filled'):
635  return a.filled(fill_value)
636  elif isinstance(a, ndarray):
637  # Should we check for contiguity ? and a.flags['CONTIGUOUS']:
638  return a
639  elif isinstance(a, dict):
640  return np.array(a, 'O')
641  else:
642  return np.array(a)
643 
644 
645 def get_masked_subclass(*arrays):
646  """
647  Return the youngest subclass of MaskedArray from a list of (masked) arrays.
648 
649  In case of siblings, the first listed takes over.
650 
651  """
652  if len(arrays) == 1:
653  arr = arrays[0]
654  if isinstance(arr, MaskedArray):
655  rcls = type(arr)
656  else:
657  rcls = MaskedArray
658  else:
659  arrcls = [type(a) for a in arrays]
660  rcls = arrcls[0]
661  if not issubclass(rcls, MaskedArray):
662  rcls = MaskedArray
663  for cls in arrcls[1:]:
664  if issubclass(cls, rcls):
665  rcls = cls
666  # Don't return MaskedConstant as result: revert to MaskedArray
667  if rcls.__name__ == 'MaskedConstant':
668  return MaskedArray
669  return rcls
670

672 def getdata(a, subok=True):
673  """
674  Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray.
675 
676  Return the data of `a` (if any) as an ndarray if `a` is a ``MaskedArray``,
677  else return `a` as a ndarray or subclass (depending on `subok`) if not.
678 
679  Parameters
680  ----------
681  a : array_like
682  Input ``MaskedArray``, alternatively a ndarray or a subclass thereof.
683  subok : bool
684  Whether to force the output to be a `pure` ndarray (False) or to
685  return a subclass of ndarray if appropriate (True, default).
686 
687  See Also
688  --------
689  getmask : Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask.
690  getmaskarray : Return the mask of a masked array, or full array of False.
691 
692  Examples
693  --------
694  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
695  >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2)
696  >>> a
697  masked_array(data =
698  [[1 --]
699  [3 4]],
700  mask =
701  [[False True]
702  [False False]],
703  fill_value=999999)
704  >>> ma.getdata(a)
705  array([[1, 2],
706  [3, 4]])
707 
708  Equivalently use the ``MaskedArray`` `data` attribute.
709 
710  >>> a.data
711  array([[1, 2],
712  [3, 4]])
713 
714  """
715  try:
716  data = a._data
717  except AttributeError:
718  data = np.array(a, copy=False, subok=subok)
719  if not subok:
720  return data.view(ndarray)
721  return data

724 get_data = getdata
725 
726 
727 def fix_invalid(a, mask=nomask, copy=True, fill_value=None):
728  """
729  Return input with invalid data masked and replaced by a fill value.
730 
731  Invalid data means values of `nan`, `inf`, etc.
732 
733  Parameters
734  ----------
735  a : array_like
736  Input array, a (subclass of) ndarray.
737  mask : sequence, optional
738  Mask. Must be convertible to an array of booleans with the same
739  shape as `data`. True indicates a masked (i.e. invalid) data.
740  copy : bool, optional
741  Whether to use a copy of `a` (True) or to fix `a` in place (False).
742  Default is True.
743  fill_value : scalar, optional
744  Value used for fixing invalid data. Default is None, in which case
745  the ``a.fill_value`` is used.
746 
747  Returns
748  -------
749  b : MaskedArray
750  The input array with invalid entries fixed.
751 
752  Notes
753  -----
754  A copy is performed by default.
755 
756  Examples
757  --------
758  >>> x = np.ma.array([1., -1, np.nan, np.inf], mask=[1] + [0]*3)
759  >>> x
760  masked_array(data = [-- -1.0 nan inf],
761  mask = [ True False False False],
762  fill_value = 1e+20)
763  >>> np.ma.fix_invalid(x)
764  masked_array(data = [-- -1.0 -- --],
765  mask = [ True False True True],
766  fill_value = 1e+20)
767 
768  >>> fixed = np.ma.fix_invalid(x)
769  >>> fixed.data
770  array([ 1.00000000e+00, -1.00000000e+00, 1.00000000e+20,
771  1.00000000e+20])
772  >>> x.data
773  array([ 1., -1., NaN, Inf])
774 
775  """
776  a = masked_array(a, copy=copy, mask=mask, subok=True)
777  invalid = np.logical_not(np.isfinite(a._data))
778  if not invalid.any():
779  return a
780  a._mask |= invalid
781  if fill_value is None:
782  fill_value = a.fill_value
783  a._data[invalid] = fill_value
784  return a
785

788 # Ufuncs #
789 ###############################################################################

792 ufunc_domain = {}
793 ufunc_fills = {}

795 
796 class _DomainCheckInterval:
797  """
798  Define a valid interval, so that :
799 
800  ``domain_check_interval(a,b)(x) == True`` where
801  ``x < a`` or ``x > b``.
802 
803  """
804 
805  def __init__(self, a, b):
806  "domain_check_interval(a,b)(x) = true where x < a or y > b"
807  if (a > b):
808  (a, b) = (b, a)
809  self.a = a
810  self.b = b
811 
812  def __call__(self, x):
813  "Execute the call behavior."
814  # nans at masked positions cause RuntimeWarnings, even though
815  # they are masked. To avoid this we suppress warnings.
816  with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
817  return umath.logical_or(umath.greater(x, self.b),
818  umath.less(x, self.a))
819 
820 
821 class _DomainTan:
822  """
823  Define a valid interval for the `tan` function, so that:
824 
825  ``domain_tan(eps) = True`` where ``abs(cos(x)) < eps``
826 
827  """
828 
829  def __init__(self, eps):
830  "domain_tan(eps) = true where abs(cos(x)) < eps)"
831  self.eps = eps
832 
833  def __call__(self, x):
834  "Executes the call behavior."
835  with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
836  return umath.less(umath.absolute(umath.cos(x)), self.eps)

839 class _DomainSafeDivide:
840  """
841  Define a domain for safe division.
842 
843  """
844 
845  def __init__(self, tolerance=None):
846  self.tolerance = tolerance
847 
848  def __call__(self, a, b):
849  # Delay the selection of the tolerance to here in order to reduce numpy
850  # import times. The calculation of these parameters is a substantial
851  # component of numpy's import time.
852  if self.tolerance is None:
853  self.tolerance = np.finfo(float).tiny
854  # don't call ma ufuncs from __array_wrap__ which would fail for scalars
855  a, b = np.asarray(a), np.asarray(b)
856  with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
857  return umath.absolute(a) * self.tolerance >= umath.absolute(b)

860 class _DomainGreater:
861  """
862  DomainGreater(v)(x) is True where x <= v.
863 
864  """
865 
866  def __init__(self, critical_value):
867  "DomainGreater(v)(x) = true where x <= v"
868  self.critical_value = critical_value
869 
870  def __call__(self, x):
871  "Executes the call behavior."
872  with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
873  return umath.less_equal(x, self.critical_value)

876 class _DomainGreaterEqual:
877  """
878  DomainGreaterEqual(v)(x) is True where x < v.
879 
880  """
881 
882  def __init__(self, critical_value):
883  "DomainGreaterEqual(v)(x) = true where x < v"
884  self.critical_value = critical_value
885 
886  def __call__(self, x):
887  "Executes the call behavior."
888  with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
889  return umath.less(x, self.critical_value)

891 
892 class _MaskedUnaryOperation:
893  """
894  Defines masked version of unary operations, where invalid values are
895  pre-masked.
896 
897  Parameters
898  ----------
899  mufunc : callable
900  The function for which to define a masked version. Made available
901  as ``_MaskedUnaryOperation.f``.
902  fill : scalar, optional
903  Filling value, default is 0.
904  domain : class instance
905  Domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*``
906  classes. Default is None.
907 
908  """
909 
910  def __init__(self, mufunc, fill=0, domain=None):
911  self.f = mufunc
912  self.fill = fill
913  self.domain = domain
914  self.__doc__ = getattr(mufunc, "__doc__", str(mufunc))
915  self.__name__ = getattr(mufunc, "__name__", str(mufunc))
916  ufunc_domain[mufunc] = domain
917  ufunc_fills[mufunc] = fill
918 
919  def __call__(self, a, *args, **kwargs):
920  """
921  Execute the call behavior.
922 
923  """
924  d = getdata(a)
925  # Deal with domain
926  if self.domain is not None:
927  # Case 1.1. : Domained function
928  # nans at masked positions cause RuntimeWarnings, even though
929  # they are masked. To avoid this we suppress warnings.
930  with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
931  result = self.f(d, *args, **kwargs)
932  # Make a mask
933  m = ~umath.isfinite(result)
934  m |= self.domain(d)
935  m |= getmask(a)
936  else:
937  # Case 1.2. : Function without a domain
938  # Get the result and the mask
939  with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
940  result = self.f(d, *args, **kwargs)
941  m = getmask(a)
942 
943  if not result.ndim:
944  # Case 2.1. : The result is scalarscalar
945  if m:
946  return masked
947  return result
948 
949  if m is not nomask:
950  # Case 2.2. The result is an array
951  # We need to fill the invalid data back w/ the input Now,
952  # that's plain silly: in C, we would just skip the element and
953  # keep the original, but we do have to do it that way in Python
954 
955  # In case result has a lower dtype than the inputs (as in
956  # equal)
957  try:
958  np.copyto(result, d, where=m)
959  except TypeError:
960  pass
961  # Transform to
962  masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a))
963  masked_result._mask = m
964  masked_result._update_from(a)
965  return masked_result
966 
967  def __str__(self):
968  return "Masked version of %s. [Invalid values are masked]" % str(self.f)
969 
970 
971 class _MaskedBinaryOperation:
972  """
973  Define masked version of binary operations, where invalid
974  values are pre-masked.
975 
976  Parameters
977  ----------
978  mbfunc : function
979  The function for which to define a masked version. Made available
980  as ``_MaskedBinaryOperation.f``.
981  domain : class instance
982  Default domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*``
983  classes. Default is None.
984  fillx : scalar, optional
985  Filling value for the first argument, default is 0.
986  filly : scalar, optional
987  Filling value for the second argument, default is 0.
988 
989  """
990 
991  def __init__(self, mbfunc, fillx=0, filly=0):
992  """
993  abfunc(fillx, filly) must be defined.
994 
995  abfunc(x, filly) = x for all x to enable reduce.
996 
997  """
998  self.f = mbfunc
999  self.fillx = fillx
1000  self.filly = filly
1001  self.__doc__ = getattr(mbfunc, "__doc__", str(mbfunc))
1002  self.__name__ = getattr(mbfunc, "__name__", str(mbfunc))
1003  ufunc_domain[mbfunc] = None
1004  ufunc_fills[mbfunc] = (fillx, filly)
1005 
1006  def __call__(self, a, b, *args, **kwargs):
1007  """
1008  Execute the call behavior.
1009 
1010  """
1011  # Get the data, as ndarray
1012  (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b))
1013  # Get the result
1014  with np.errstate():
1015  np.seterr(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore')
1016  result = self.f(da, db, *args, **kwargs)
1017  # Get the mask for the result
1018  (ma, mb) = (getmask(a), getmask(b))
1019  if ma is nomask:
1020  if mb is nomask:
1021  m = nomask
1022  else:
1023  m = umath.logical_or(getmaskarray(a), mb)
1024  elif mb is nomask:
1025  m = umath.logical_or(ma, getmaskarray(b))
1026  else:
1027  m = umath.logical_or(ma, mb)
1028 
1029  # Case 1. : scalar
1030  if not result.ndim:
1031  if m:
1032  return masked
1033  return result
1034 
1035  # Case 2. : array
1036  # Revert result to da where masked
1037  if m is not nomask and m.any():
1038  # any errors, just abort; impossible to guarantee masked values
1039  try:
1040  np.copyto(result, da, casting='unsafe', where=m)
1041  except:
1042  pass
1043 
1044  # Transforms to a (subclass of) MaskedArray
1045  masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b))
1046  masked_result._mask = m
1047  if isinstance(a, MaskedArray):
1048  masked_result._update_from(a)
1049  elif isinstance(b, MaskedArray):
1050  masked_result._update_from(b)
1051  return masked_result
1052 
1053  def reduce(self, target, axis=0, dtype=None):
1054  """
1055  Reduce `target` along the given `axis`.
1056 
1057  """
1058  tclass = get_masked_subclass(target)
1059  m = getmask(target)
1060  t = filled(target, self.filly)
1061  if t.shape == ():
1062  t = t.reshape(1)
1063  if m is not nomask:
1064  m = make_mask(m, copy=1)
1065  m.shape = (1,)
1066 
1067  if m is nomask:
1068  tr = self.f.reduce(t, axis)
1069  mr = nomask
1070  else:
1071  tr = self.f.reduce(t, axis, dtype=dtype or t.dtype)
1072  mr = umath.logical_and.reduce(m, axis)
1073 
1074  if not tr.shape:
1075  if mr:
1076  return masked
1077  else:
1078  return tr
1079  masked_tr = tr.view(tclass)
1080  masked_tr._mask = mr
1081  return masked_tr
1082 
1083  def outer(self, a, b):
1084  """
1085  Return the function applied to the outer product of a and b.
1086 
1087  """
1088  (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b))
1089  d = self.f.outer(da, db)
1090  ma = getmask(a)
1091  mb = getmask(b)
1092  if ma is nomask and mb is nomask:
1093  m = nomask
1094  else:
1095  ma = getmaskarray(a)
1096  mb = getmaskarray(b)
1097  m = umath.logical_or.outer(ma, mb)
1098  if (not m.ndim) and m:
1099  return masked
1100  if m is not nomask:
1101  np.copyto(d, da, where=m)
1102  if not d.shape:
1103  return d
1104  masked_d = d.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b))
1105  masked_d._mask = m
1106  return masked_d
1107 
1108  def accumulate(self, target, axis=0):
1109  """Accumulate `target` along `axis` after filling with y fill
1110  value.
1111 
1112  """
1113  tclass = get_masked_subclass(target)
1114  t = filled(target, self.filly)
1115  result = self.f.accumulate(t, axis)
1116  masked_result = result.view(tclass)
1117  return masked_result
1118 
1119  def __str__(self):
1120  return "Masked version of " + str(self.f)
1121 
1122 
1123 class _DomainedBinaryOperation:
1124  """
1125  Define binary operations that have a domain, like divide.
1126 
1127  They have no reduce, outer or accumulate.
1128 
1129  Parameters
1130  ----------
1131  mbfunc : function
1132  The function for which to define a masked version. Made available
1133  as ``_DomainedBinaryOperation.f``.
1134  domain : class instance
1135  Default domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*``
1136  classes.
1137  fillx : scalar, optional
1138  Filling value for the first argument, default is 0.
1139  filly : scalar, optional
1140  Filling value for the second argument, default is 0.
1141 
1142  """
1143 
1144  def __init__(self, dbfunc, domain, fillx=0, filly=0):
1145  """abfunc(fillx, filly) must be defined.
1146  abfunc(x, filly) = x for all x to enable reduce.
1147  """
1148  self.f = dbfunc
1149  self.domain = domain
1150  self.fillx = fillx
1151  self.filly = filly
1152  self.__doc__ = getattr(dbfunc, "__doc__", str(dbfunc))
1153  self.__name__ = getattr(dbfunc, "__name__", str(dbfunc))
1154  ufunc_domain[dbfunc] = domain
1155  ufunc_fills[dbfunc] = (fillx, filly)
1156 
1157  def __call__(self, a, b, *args, **kwargs):
1158  "Execute the call behavior."
1159  # Get the data
1160  (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b))
1161  # Get the result
1162  with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
1163  result = self.f(da, db, *args, **kwargs)
1164  # Get the mask as a combination of the source masks and invalid
1165  m = ~umath.isfinite(result)
1166  m |= getmask(a)
1167  m |= getmask(b)
1168  # Apply the domain
1169  domain = ufunc_domain.get(self.f, None)
1170  if domain is not None:
1171  m |= domain(da, db)
1172  # Take care of the scalar case first
1173  if (not m.ndim):
1174  if m:
1175  return masked
1176  else:
1177  return result
1178  # When the mask is True, put back da if possible
1179  # any errors, just abort; impossible to guarantee masked values
1180  try:
1181  np.copyto(result, 0, casting='unsafe', where=m)
1182  # avoid using "*" since this may be overlaid
1183  masked_da = umath.multiply(m, da)
1184  # only add back if it can be cast safely
1185  if np.can_cast(masked_da.dtype, result.dtype, casting='safe'):
1186  result += masked_da
1187  except:
1188  pass
1189 
1190  # Transforms to a (subclass of) MaskedArray
1191  masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b))
1192  masked_result._mask = m
1193  if isinstance(a, MaskedArray):
1194  masked_result._update_from(a)
1195  elif isinstance(b, MaskedArray):
1196  masked_result._update_from(b)
1197  return masked_result
1198 
1199  def __str__(self):
1200  return "Masked version of " + str(self.f)

1286 
1287 def _recursive_make_descr(datatype, newtype=bool_):
1288  "Private function allowing recursion in make_descr."
1289  # Do we have some name fields ?
1290  if datatype.names:
1291  descr = []
1292  for name in datatype.names:
1293  field = datatype.fields[name]
1294  if len(field) == 3:
1295  # Prepend the title to the name
1296  name = (field[-1], name)
1297  descr.append((name, _recursive_make_descr(field[0], newtype)))
1298  return descr
1299  # Is this some kind of composite a la (np.float,2)
1300  elif datatype.subdtype:
1301  mdescr = list(datatype.subdtype)
1302  mdescr[0] = _recursive_make_descr(datatype.subdtype[0], newtype)
1303  return tuple(mdescr)
1304  else:
1305  return newtype
1306 
1307 
1308 def make_mask_descr(ndtype):
1309  """
1310  Construct a dtype description list from a given dtype.
1311 
1312  Returns a new dtype object, with the type of all fields in `ndtype` to a
1313  boolean type. Field names are not altered.
1314 
1315  Parameters
1316  ----------
1317  ndtype : dtype
1318  The dtype to convert.
1319 
1320  Returns
1321  -------
1322  result : dtype
1323  A dtype that looks like `ndtype`, the type of all fields is boolean.
1324 
1325  Examples
1326  --------
1327  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
1328  >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['foo', 'bar'],
1329  'formats':[np.float32, np.int]})
1330  >>> dtype
1331  dtype([('foo', '<f4'), ('bar', '<i4')])
1332  >>> ma.make_mask_descr(dtype)
1333  dtype([('foo', '|b1'), ('bar', '|b1')])
1334  >>> ma.make_mask_descr(np.float32)
1335  <type 'numpy.bool_'>
1336 
1337  """
1338  # Make sure we do have a dtype
1339  if not isinstance(ndtype, np.dtype):
1340  ndtype = np.dtype(ndtype)
1341  return np.dtype(_recursive_make_descr(ndtype, np.bool))
1342 
1343 
1344 def getmask(a):
1345  """
1346  Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask.
1347 
1348  Return the mask of `a` as an ndarray if `a` is a `MaskedArray` and the
1349  mask is not `nomask`, else return `nomask`. To guarantee a full array
1350  of booleans of the same shape as a, use `getmaskarray`.
1351 
1352  Parameters
1353  ----------
1354  a : array_like
1355  Input `MaskedArray` for which the mask is required.
1356 
1357  See Also
1358  --------
1359  getdata : Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray.
1360  getmaskarray : Return the mask of a masked array, or full array of False.
1361 
1362  Examples
1363  --------
1364  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
1365  >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2)
1366  >>> a
1367  masked_array(data =
1368  [[1 --]
1369  [3 4]],
1370  mask =
1371  [[False True]
1372  [False False]],
1373  fill_value=999999)
1374  >>> ma.getmask(a)
1375  array([[False, True],
1376  [False, False]], dtype=bool)
1377 
1378  Equivalently use the `MaskedArray` `mask` attribute.
1379 
1380  >>> a.mask
1381  array([[False, True],
1382  [False, False]], dtype=bool)
1383 
1384  Result when mask == `nomask`
1385 
1386  >>> b = ma.masked_array([[1,2],[3,4]])
1387  >>> b
1388  masked_array(data =
1389  [[1 2]
1390  [3 4]],
1391  mask =
1392  False,
1393  fill_value=999999)
1394  >>> ma.nomask
1395  False
1396  >>> ma.getmask(b) == ma.nomask
1397  True
1398  >>> b.mask == ma.nomask
1399  True
1400 
1401  """
1402  return getattr(a, '_mask', nomask)
1403 
1404 
1405 get_mask = getmask
1406 
1407 
1408 def getmaskarray(arr):
1409  """
1410  Return the mask of a masked array, or full boolean array of False.
1411 
1412  Return the mask of `arr` as an ndarray if `arr` is a `MaskedArray` and
1413  the mask is not `nomask`, else return a full boolean array of False of
1414  the same shape as `arr`.
1415 
1416  Parameters
1417  ----------
1418  arr : array_like
1419  Input `MaskedArray` for which the mask is required.
1420 
1421  See Also
1422  --------
1423  getmask : Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask.
1424  getdata : Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray.
1425 
1426  Examples
1427  --------
1428  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
1429  >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2)
1430  >>> a
1431  masked_array(data =
1432  [[1 --]
1433  [3 4]],
1434  mask =
1435  [[False True]
1436  [False False]],
1437  fill_value=999999)
1438  >>> ma.getmaskarray(a)
1439  array([[False, True],
1440  [False, False]], dtype=bool)
1441 
1442  Result when mask == ``nomask``
1443 
1444  >>> b = ma.masked_array([[1,2],[3,4]])
1445  >>> b
1446  masked_array(data =
1447  [[1 2]
1448  [3 4]],
1449  mask =
1450  False,
1451  fill_value=999999)
1452  >>> >ma.getmaskarray(b)
1453  array([[False, False],
1454  [False, False]], dtype=bool)
1455 
1456  """
1457  mask = getmask(arr)
1458  if mask is nomask:
1459  mask = make_mask_none(np.shape(arr), getattr(arr, 'dtype', None))
1460  return mask
1461 
1462 
1463 def is_mask(m):
1464  """
1465  Return True if m is a valid, standard mask.
1466 
1467  This function does not check the contents of the input, only that the
1468  type is MaskType. In particular, this function returns False if the
1469  mask has a flexible dtype.
1470 
1471  Parameters
1472  ----------
1473  m : array_like
1474  Array to test.
1475 
1476  Returns
1477  -------
1478  result : bool
1479  True if `m.dtype.type` is MaskType, False otherwise.
1480 
1481  See Also
1482  --------
1483  isMaskedArray : Test whether input is an instance of MaskedArray.
1484 
1485  Examples
1486  --------
1487  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
1488  >>> m = ma.masked_equal([0, 1, 0, 2, 3], 0)
1489  >>> m
1490  masked_array(data = [-- 1 -- 2 3],
1491  mask = [ True False True False False],
1492  fill_value=999999)
1493  >>> ma.is_mask(m)
1494  False
1495  >>> ma.is_mask(m.mask)
1496  True
1497 
1498  Input must be an ndarray (or have similar attributes)
1499  for it to be considered a valid mask.
1500 
1501  >>> m = [False, True, False]
1502  >>> ma.is_mask(m)
1503  False
1504  >>> m = np.array([False, True, False])
1505  >>> m
1506  array([False, True, False], dtype=bool)
1507  >>> ma.is_mask(m)
1508  True
1509 
1510  Arrays with complex dtypes don't return True.
1511 
1512  >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['monty', 'pithon'],
1513  'formats':[np.bool, np.bool]})
1514  >>> dtype
1515  dtype([('monty', '|b1'), ('pithon', '|b1')])
1516  >>> m = np.array([(True, False), (False, True), (True, False)],
1517  dtype=dtype)
1518  >>> m
1519  array([(True, False), (False, True), (True, False)],
1520  dtype=[('monty', '|b1'), ('pithon', '|b1')])
1521  >>> ma.is_mask(m)
1522  False
1523 
1524  """
1525  try:
1526  return m.dtype.type is MaskType
1527  except AttributeError:
1528  return False
1529 
1530 
1531 def make_mask(m, copy=False, shrink=True, dtype=MaskType):
1532  """
1533  Create a boolean mask from an array.
1534 
1535  Return `m` as a boolean mask, creating a copy if necessary or requested.
1536  The function can accept any sequence that is convertible to integers,
1537  or ``nomask``. Does not require that contents must be 0s and 1s, values
1538  of 0 are interepreted as False, everything else as True.
1539 
1540  Parameters
1541  ----------
1542  m : array_like
1543  Potential mask.
1544  copy : bool, optional
1545  Whether to return a copy of `m` (True) or `m` itself (False).
1546  shrink : bool, optional
1547  Whether to shrink `m` to ``nomask`` if all its values are False.
1548  dtype : dtype, optional
1549  Data-type of the output mask. By default, the output mask has a
1550  dtype of MaskType (bool). If the dtype is flexible, each field has
1551  a boolean dtype. This is ignored when `m` is ``nomask``, in which
1552  case ``nomask`` is always returned.
1553 
1554  Returns
1555  -------
1556  result : ndarray
1557  A boolean mask derived from `m`.
1558 
1559  Examples
1560  --------
1561  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
1562  >>> m = [True, False, True, True]
1563  >>> ma.make_mask(m)
1564  array([ True, False, True, True], dtype=bool)
1565  >>> m = [1, 0, 1, 1]
1566  >>> ma.make_mask(m)
1567  array([ True, False, True, True], dtype=bool)
1568  >>> m = [1, 0, 2, -3]
1569  >>> ma.make_mask(m)
1570  array([ True, False, True, True], dtype=bool)
1571 
1572  Effect of the `shrink` parameter.
1573 
1574  >>> m = np.zeros(4)
1575  >>> m
1576  array([ 0., 0., 0., 0.])
1577  >>> ma.make_mask(m)
1578  False
1579  >>> ma.make_mask(m, shrink=False)
1580  array([False, False, False, False], dtype=bool)
1581 
1582  Using a flexible `dtype`.
1583 
1584  >>> m = [1, 0, 1, 1]
1585  >>> n = [0, 1, 0, 0]
1586  >>> arr = []
1587  >>> for man, mouse in zip(m, n):
1588  ... arr.append((man, mouse))
1589  >>> arr
1590  [(1, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 0)]
1591  >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['man', 'mouse'],
1592  'formats':[np.int, np.int]})
1593  >>> arr = np.array(arr, dtype=dtype)
1594  >>> arr
1595  array([(1, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 0)],
1596  dtype=[('man', '<i4'), ('mouse', '<i4')])
1597  >>> ma.make_mask(arr, dtype=dtype)
1598  array([(True, False), (False, True), (True, False), (True, False)],
1599  dtype=[('man', '|b1'), ('mouse', '|b1')])
1600 
1601  """
1602  if m is nomask:
1603  return nomask
1604  elif isinstance(m, ndarray):
1605  # We won't return after this point to make sure we can shrink the mask
1606  # Fill the mask in case there are missing data
1607  m = filled(m, True)
1608  # Make sure the input dtype is valid
1609  dtype = make_mask_descr(dtype)
1610  if m.dtype == dtype:
1611  if copy:
1612  result = m.copy()
1613  else:
1614  result = m
1615  else:
1616  result = np.array(m, dtype=dtype, copy=copy)
1617  else:
1618  result = np.array(filled(m, True), dtype=MaskType)
1619  # Bas les masques !
1620  if shrink and (not result.dtype.names) and (not result.any()):
1621  return nomask
1622  else:
1623  return result
1624 
1625 
1626 def make_mask_none(newshape, dtype=None):
1627  """
1628  Return a boolean mask of the given shape, filled with False.
1629 
1630  This function returns a boolean ndarray with all entries False, that can
1631  be used in common mask manipulations. If a complex dtype is specified, the
1632  type of each field is converted to a boolean type.
1633 
1634  Parameters
1635  ----------
1636  newshape : tuple
1637  A tuple indicating the shape of the mask.
1638  dtype : {None, dtype}, optional
1639  If None, use a MaskType instance. Otherwise, use a new datatype with
1640  the same fields as `dtype`, converted to boolean types.
1641 
1642  Returns
1643  -------
1644  result : ndarray
1645  An ndarray of appropriate shape and dtype, filled with False.
1646 
1647  See Also
1648  --------
1649  make_mask : Create a boolean mask from an array.
1650  make_mask_descr : Construct a dtype description list from a given dtype.
1651 
1652  Examples
1653  --------
1654  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
1655  >>> ma.make_mask_none((3,))
1656  array([False, False, False], dtype=bool)
1657 
1658  Defining a more complex dtype.
1659 
1660  >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['foo', 'bar'],
1661  'formats':[np.float32, np.int]})
1662  >>> dtype
1663  dtype([('foo', '<f4'), ('bar', '<i4')])
1664  >>> ma.make_mask_none((3,), dtype=dtype)
1665  array([(False, False), (False, False), (False, False)],
1666  dtype=[('foo', '|b1'), ('bar', '|b1')])
1667 
1668  """
1669  if dtype is None:
1670  result = np.zeros(newshape, dtype=MaskType)
1671  else:
1672  result = np.zeros(newshape, dtype=make_mask_descr(dtype))
1673  return result
1674 
1675 
1676 def mask_or(m1, m2, copy=False, shrink=True):
1677  """
1678  Combine two masks with the ``logical_or`` operator.
1679 
1680  The result may be a view on `m1` or `m2` if the other is `nomask`
1681  (i.e. False).
1682 
1683  Parameters
1684  ----------
1685  m1, m2 : array_like
1686  Input masks.
1687  copy : bool, optional
1688  If copy is False and one of the inputs is `nomask`, return a view
1689  of the other input mask. Defaults to False.
1690  shrink : bool, optional
1691  Whether to shrink the output to `nomask` if all its values are
1692  False. Defaults to True.
1693 
1694  Returns
1695  -------
1696  mask : output mask
1697  The result masks values that are masked in either `m1` or `m2`.
1698 
1699  Raises
1700  ------
1701  ValueError
1702  If `m1` and `m2` have different flexible dtypes.
1703 
1704  Examples
1705  --------
1706  >>> m1 = np.ma.make_mask([0, 1, 1, 0])
1707  >>> m2 = np.ma.make_mask([1, 0, 0, 0])
1708  >>> np.ma.mask_or(m1, m2)
1709  array([ True, True, True, False], dtype=bool)
1710 
1711  """
1712 
1713  def _recursive_mask_or(m1, m2, newmask):
1714  names = m1.dtype.names
1715  for name in names:
1716  current1 = m1[name]
1717  if current1.dtype.names:
1718  _recursive_mask_or(current1, m2[name], newmask[name])
1719  else:
1720  umath.logical_or(current1, m2[name], newmask[name])
1721  return
1722 
1723  if (m1 is nomask) or (m1 is False):
1724  dtype = getattr(m2, 'dtype', MaskType)
1725  return make_mask(m2, copy=copy, shrink=shrink, dtype=dtype)
1726  if (m2 is nomask) or (m2 is False):
1727  dtype = getattr(m1, 'dtype', MaskType)
1728  return make_mask(m1, copy=copy, shrink=shrink, dtype=dtype)
1729  if m1 is m2 and is_mask(m1):
1730  return m1
1731  (dtype1, dtype2) = (getattr(m1, 'dtype', None), getattr(m2, 'dtype', None))
1732  if (dtype1 != dtype2):
1733  raise ValueError("Incompatible dtypes '%s'<>'%s'" % (dtype1, dtype2))
1734  if dtype1.names:
1735  newmask = np.empty_like(m1)
1736  _recursive_mask_or(m1, m2, newmask)
1737  return newmask
1738  return make_mask(umath.logical_or(m1, m2), copy=copy, shrink=shrink)
1739 
1740 
1741 def flatten_mask(mask):
1742  """
1743  Returns a completely flattened version of the mask, where nested fields
1744  are collapsed.
1745 
1746  Parameters
1747  ----------
1748  mask : array_like
1749  Input array, which will be interpreted as booleans.
1750 
1751  Returns
1752  -------
1753  flattened_mask : ndarray of bools
1754  The flattened input.
1755 
1756  Examples
1757  --------
1758  >>> mask = np.array([0, 0, 1], dtype=np.bool)
1759  >>> flatten_mask(mask)
1760  array([False, False, True], dtype=bool)
1761 
1762  >>> mask = np.array([(0, 0), (0, 1)], dtype=[('a', bool), ('b', bool)])
1763  >>> flatten_mask(mask)
1764  array([False, False, False, True], dtype=bool)
1765 
1766  >>> mdtype = [('a', bool), ('b', [('ba', bool), ('bb', bool)])]
1767  >>> mask = np.array([(0, (0, 0)), (0, (0, 1))], dtype=mdtype)
1768  >>> flatten_mask(mask)
1769  array([False, False, False, False, False, True], dtype=bool)
1770 
1771  """
1772 
1773  def _flatmask(mask):
1774  "Flatten the mask and returns a (maybe nested) sequence of booleans."
1775  mnames = mask.dtype.names
1776  if mnames:
1777  return [flatten_mask(mask[name]) for name in mnames]
1778  else:
1779  return mask
1780 
1781  def _flatsequence(sequence):
1782  "Generates a flattened version of the sequence."
1783  try:
1784  for element in sequence:
1785  if hasattr(element, '__iter__'):
1786  for f in _flatsequence(element):
1787  yield f
1788  else:
1789  yield element
1790  except TypeError:
1791  yield sequence
1792 
1793  mask = np.asarray(mask)
1794  flattened = _flatsequence(_flatmask(mask))
1795  return np.array([_ for _ in flattened], dtype=bool)
1796 
1797 
1798 def _check_mask_axis(mask, axis, keepdims=np._NoValue):
1799  "Check whether there are masked values along the given axis"
1800  kwargs = {} if keepdims is np._NoValue else {'keepdims': keepdims}
1801  if mask is not nomask:
1802  return mask.all(axis=axis, **kwargs)
1803  return nomask
1804

1806 ###############################################################################
1807 # Masking functions #
1808 ###############################################################################
1809 
1810 def masked_where(condition, a, copy=True):
1811  """
1812  Mask an array where a condition is met.
1813 
1814  Return `a` as an array masked where `condition` is True.
1815  Any masked values of `a` or `condition` are also masked in the output.
1816 
1817  Parameters
1818  ----------
1819  condition : array_like
1820  Masking condition. When `condition` tests floating point values for
1821  equality, consider using ``masked_values`` instead.
1822  a : array_like
1823  Array to mask.
1824  copy : bool
1825  If True (default) make a copy of `a` in the result. If False modify
1826  `a` in place and return a view.
1827 
1828  Returns
1829  -------
1830  result : MaskedArray
1831  The result of masking `a` where `condition` is True.
1832 
1833  See Also
1834  --------
1835  masked_values : Mask using floating point equality.
1836  masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value.
1837  masked_not_equal : Mask where `not` equal to a given value.
1838  masked_less_equal : Mask where less than or equal to a given value.
1839  masked_greater_equal : Mask where greater than or equal to a given value.
1840  masked_less : Mask where less than a given value.
1841  masked_greater : Mask where greater than a given value.
1842  masked_inside : Mask inside a given interval.
1843  masked_outside : Mask outside a given interval.
1844  masked_invalid : Mask invalid values (NaNs or infs).
1845 
1846  Examples
1847  --------
1848  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
1849  >>> a = np.arange(4)
1850  >>> a
1851  array([0, 1, 2, 3])
1852  >>> ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a)
1853  masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3],
1854  mask = [ True True True False],
1855  fill_value=999999)
1856 
1857  Mask array `b` conditional on `a`.
1858 
1859  >>> b = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']
1860  >>> ma.masked_where(a == 2, b)
1861  masked_array(data = [a b -- d],
1862  mask = [False False True False],
1863  fill_value=N/A)
1864 
1865  Effect of the `copy` argument.
1866 
1867  >>> c = ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a)
1868  >>> c
1869  masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3],
1870  mask = [ True True True False],
1871  fill_value=999999)
1872  >>> c[0] = 99
1873  >>> c
1874  masked_array(data = [99 -- -- 3],
1875  mask = [False True True False],
1876  fill_value=999999)
1877  >>> a
1878  array([0, 1, 2, 3])
1879  >>> c = ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a, copy=False)
1880  >>> c[0] = 99
1881  >>> c
1882  masked_array(data = [99 -- -- 3],
1883  mask = [False True True False],
1884  fill_value=999999)
1885  >>> a
1886  array([99, 1, 2, 3])
1887 
1888  When `condition` or `a` contain masked values.
1889 
1890  >>> a = np.arange(4)
1891  >>> a = ma.masked_where(a == 2, a)
1892  >>> a
1893  masked_array(data = [0 1 -- 3],
1894  mask = [False False True False],
1895  fill_value=999999)
1896  >>> b = np.arange(4)
1897  >>> b = ma.masked_where(b == 0, b)
1898  >>> b
1899  masked_array(data = [-- 1 2 3],
1900  mask = [ True False False False],
1901  fill_value=999999)
1902  >>> ma.masked_where(a == 3, b)
1903  masked_array(data = [-- 1 -- --],
1904  mask = [ True False True True],
1905  fill_value=999999)
1906 
1907  """
1908  # Make sure that condition is a valid standard-type mask.
1909  cond = make_mask(condition)
1910  a = np.array(a, copy=copy, subok=True)
1911 
1912  (cshape, ashape) = (cond.shape, a.shape)
1913  if cshape and cshape != ashape:
1914  raise IndexError("Inconsistant shape between the condition and the input"
1915  " (got %s and %s)" % (cshape, ashape))
1916  if hasattr(a, '_mask'):
1917  cond = mask_or(cond, a._mask)
1918  cls = type(a)
1919  else:
1920  cls = MaskedArray
1921  result = a.view(cls)
1922  # Assign to *.mask so that structured masks are handled correctly.
1923  result.mask = cond
1924  return result
1925 
1926 
1927 def masked_greater(x, value, copy=True):
1928  """
1929  Mask an array where greater than a given value.
1930 
1931  This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with
1932  `condition` = (x > value).
1933 
1934  See Also
1935  --------
1936  masked_where : Mask where a condition is met.
1937 
1938  Examples
1939  --------
1940  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
1941  >>> a = np.arange(4)
1942  >>> a
1943  array([0, 1, 2, 3])
1944  >>> ma.masked_greater(a, 2)
1945  masked_array(data = [0 1 2 --],
1946  mask = [False False False True],
1947  fill_value=999999)
1948 
1949  """
1950  return masked_where(greater(x, value), x, copy=copy)

2057 def masked_equal(x, value, copy=True):
2058  """
2059  Mask an array where equal to a given value.
2060 
2061  This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with
2062  `condition` = (x == value). For floating point arrays,
2063  consider using ``masked_values(x, value)``.
2064 
2065  See Also
2066  --------
2067  masked_where : Mask where a condition is met.
2068  masked_values : Mask using floating point equality.
2069 
2070  Examples
2071  --------
2072  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
2073  >>> a = np.arange(4)
2074  >>> a
2075  array([0, 1, 2, 3])
2076  >>> ma.masked_equal(a, 2)
2077  masked_array(data = [0 1 -- 3],
2078  mask = [False False True False],
2079  fill_value=999999)
2080 
2081  """
2082  output = masked_where(equal(x, value), x, copy=copy)
2083  output.fill_value = value
2084  return output
2085 
2086 
2087 def masked_inside(x, v1, v2, copy=True):
2088  """
2089  Mask an array inside a given interval.
2090 
2091  Shortcut to ``masked_where``, where `condition` is True for `x` inside
2092  the interval [v1,v2] (v1 <= x <= v2). The boundaries `v1` and `v2`
2093  can be given in either order.
2094 
2095  See Also
2096  --------
2097  masked_where : Mask where a condition is met.
2098 
2099  Notes
2100  -----
2101  The array `x` is prefilled with its filling value.
2102 
2103  Examples
2104  --------
2105  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
2106  >>> x = [0.31, 1.2, 0.01, 0.2, -0.4, -1.1]
2107  >>> ma.masked_inside(x, -0.3, 0.3)
2108  masked_array(data = [0.31 1.2 -- -- -0.4 -1.1],
2109  mask = [False False True True False False],
2110  fill_value=1e+20)
2111 
2112  The order of `v1` and `v2` doesn't matter.
2113 
2114  >>> ma.masked_inside(x, 0.3, -0.3)
2115  masked_array(data = [0.31 1.2 -- -- -0.4 -1.1],
2116  mask = [False False True True False False],
2117  fill_value=1e+20)
2118 
2119  """
2120  if v2 < v1:
2121  (v1, v2) = (v2, v1)
2122  xf = filled(x)
2123  condition = (xf >= v1) & (xf <= v2)
2124  return masked_where(condition, x, copy=copy)
2125 
2126 
2127 def masked_outside(x, v1, v2, copy=True):
2128  """
2129  Mask an array outside a given interval.
2130 
2131  Shortcut to ``masked_where``, where `condition` is True for `x` outside
2132  the interval [v1,v2] (x < v1)|(x > v2).
2133  The boundaries `v1` and `v2` can be given in either order.
2134 
2135  See Also
2136  --------
2137  masked_where : Mask where a condition is met.
2138 
2139  Notes
2140  -----
2141  The array `x` is prefilled with its filling value.
2142 
2143  Examples
2144  --------
2145  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
2146  >>> x = [0.31, 1.2, 0.01, 0.2, -0.4, -1.1]
2147  >>> ma.masked_outside(x, -0.3, 0.3)
2148  masked_array(data = [-- -- 0.01 0.2 -- --],
2149  mask = [ True True False False True True],
2150  fill_value=1e+20)
2151 
2152  The order of `v1` and `v2` doesn't matter.
2153 
2154  >>> ma.masked_outside(x, 0.3, -0.3)
2155  masked_array(data = [-- -- 0.01 0.2 -- --],
2156  mask = [ True True False False True True],
2157  fill_value=1e+20)
2158 
2159  """
2160  if v2 < v1:
2161  (v1, v2) = (v2, v1)
2162  xf = filled(x)
2163  condition = (xf < v1) | (xf > v2)
2164  return masked_where(condition, x, copy=copy)
2165 
2166 
2167 def masked_object(x, value, copy=True, shrink=True):
2168  """
2169  Mask the array `x` where the data are exactly equal to value.
2170 
2171  This function is similar to `masked_values`, but only suitable
2172  for object arrays: for floating point, use `masked_values` instead.
2173 
2174  Parameters
2175  ----------
2176  x : array_like
2177  Array to mask
2178  value : object
2179  Comparison value
2180  copy : {True, False}, optional
2181  Whether to return a copy of `x`.
2182  shrink : {True, False}, optional
2183  Whether to collapse a mask full of False to nomask
2184 
2185  Returns
2186  -------
2187  result : MaskedArray
2188  The result of masking `x` where equal to `value`.
2189 
2190  See Also
2191  --------
2192  masked_where : Mask where a condition is met.
2193  masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value (integers).
2194  masked_values : Mask using floating point equality.
2195 
2196  Examples
2197  --------
2198  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
2199  >>> food = np.array(['green_eggs', 'ham'], dtype=object)
2200  >>> # don't eat spoiled food
2201  >>> eat = ma.masked_object(food, 'green_eggs')
2202  >>> print(eat)
2203  [-- ham]
2204  >>> # plain ol` ham is boring
2205  >>> fresh_food = np.array(['cheese', 'ham', 'pineapple'], dtype=object)
2206  >>> eat = ma.masked_object(fresh_food, 'green_eggs')
2207  >>> print(eat)
2208  [cheese ham pineapple]
2209 
2210  Note that `mask` is set to ``nomask`` if possible.
2211 
2212  >>> eat
2213  masked_array(data = [cheese ham pineapple],
2214  mask = False,
2215  fill_value=?)
2216 
2217  """
2218  if isMaskedArray(x):
2219  condition = umath.equal(x._data, value)
2220  mask = x._mask
2221  else:
2222  condition = umath.equal(np.asarray(x), value)
2223  mask = nomask
2224  mask = mask_or(mask, make_mask(condition, shrink=shrink))
2225  return masked_array(x, mask=mask, copy=copy, fill_value=value)
2226 
2227 
2228 def masked_values(x, value, rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-8, copy=True, shrink=True):
2229  """
2230  Mask using floating point equality.
2231 
2232  Return a MaskedArray, masked where the data in array `x` are approximately
2233  equal to `value`, i.e. where the following condition is True
2234 
2235  (abs(x - value) <= atol+rtol*abs(value))
2236 
2237  The fill_value is set to `value` and the mask is set to ``nomask`` if
2238  possible. For integers, consider using ``masked_equal``.
2239 
2240  Parameters
2241  ----------
2242  x : array_like
2243  Array to mask.
2244  value : float
2245  Masking value.
2246  rtol : float, optional
2247  Tolerance parameter.
2248  atol : float, optional
2249  Tolerance parameter (1e-8).
2250  copy : bool, optional
2251  Whether to return a copy of `x`.
2252  shrink : bool, optional
2253  Whether to collapse a mask full of False to ``nomask``.
2254 
2255  Returns
2256  -------
2257  result : MaskedArray
2258  The result of masking `x` where approximately equal to `value`.
2259 
2260  See Also
2261  --------
2262  masked_where : Mask where a condition is met.
2263  masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value (integers).
2264 
2265  Examples
2266  --------
2267  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
2268  >>> x = np.array([1, 1.1, 2, 1.1, 3])
2269  >>> ma.masked_values(x, 1.1)
2270  masked_array(data = [1.0 -- 2.0 -- 3.0],
2271  mask = [False True False True False],
2272  fill_value=1.1)
2273 
2274  Note that `mask` is set to ``nomask`` if possible.
2275 
2276  >>> ma.masked_values(x, 1.5)
2277  masked_array(data = [ 1. 1.1 2. 1.1 3. ],
2278  mask = False,
2279  fill_value=1.5)
2280 
2281  For integers, the fill value will be different in general to the
2282  result of ``masked_equal``.
2283 
2284  >>> x = np.arange(5)
2285  >>> x
2286  array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4])
2287  >>> ma.masked_values(x, 2)
2288  masked_array(data = [0 1 -- 3 4],
2289  mask = [False False True False False],
2290  fill_value=2)
2291  >>> ma.masked_equal(x, 2)
2292  masked_array(data = [0 1 -- 3 4],
2293  mask = [False False True False False],
2294  fill_value=999999)
2295 
2296  """
2297  mabs = umath.absolute
2298  xnew = filled(x, value)
2299  if issubclass(xnew.dtype.type, np.floating):
2300  condition = umath.less_equal(
2301  mabs(xnew - value), atol + rtol * mabs(value))
2302  mask = getattr(x, '_mask', nomask)
2303  else:
2304  condition = umath.equal(xnew, value)
2305  mask = nomask
2306  mask = mask_or(mask, make_mask(condition, shrink=shrink), shrink=shrink)
2307  return masked_array(xnew, mask=mask, copy=copy, fill_value=value)
2308 
2309 
2310 def masked_invalid(a, copy=True):
2311  """
2312  Mask an array where invalid values occur (NaNs or infs).
2313 
2314  This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with
2315  `condition` = ~(np.isfinite(a)). Any pre-existing mask is conserved.
2316  Only applies to arrays with a dtype where NaNs or infs make sense
2317  (i.e. floating point types), but accepts any array_like object.
2318 
2319  See Also
2320  --------
2321  masked_where : Mask where a condition is met.
2322 
2323  Examples
2324  --------
2325  >>> import numpy.ma as ma
2326  >>> a = np.arange(5, dtype=np.float)
2327  >>> a[2] = np.NaN
2328  >>> a[3] = np.PINF
2329  >>> a
2330  array([ 0., 1., NaN, Inf, 4.])
2331  >>> ma.masked_invalid(a)
2332  masked_array(data = [0.0 1.0 -- -- 4.0],
2333  mask = [False False True True False],
2334  fill_value=1e+20)
2335 
2336  """
2337  a = np.array(a, copy=copy, subok=True)
2338  mask = getattr(a, '_mask', None)
2339  if mask is not None:
2340  condition = ~(np.isfinite(getdata(a)))
2341  if mask is not nomask:
2342  condition |= mask
2343  cls = type(a)
2344  else:
2345  condition = ~(np.isfinite(a))
2346  cls = MaskedArray
2347  result = a.view(cls)
2348  result._mask = condition
2349  return result

2408 def _recursive_printoption(result, mask, printopt):
2409  """
2410  Puts printoptions in result where mask is True.
2411 
2412  Private function allowing for recursion
2413 
2414  """
2415  names = result.dtype.names
2416  for name in names:
2417  (curdata, curmask) = (result[name], mask[name])
2418  if curdata.dtype.names:
2419  _recursive_printoption(curdata, curmask, printopt)
2420  else:
2421  np.copyto(curdata, printopt, where=curmask)
2422  return
2423

2425 masked_%(name)s(data =
2426  %(data)s,

2428  %(mask)s,
2429  %(nlen)s fill_value = %(fill)s)
2430 """,

2433  %(nlen)s mask = %(mask)s,

2456 def _recursive_filled(a, mask, fill_value):
2457  """
2458  Recursively fill `a` with `fill_value`.
2459 
2460  """
2461  names = a.dtype.names
2462  for name in names:
2463  current = a[name]
2464  if current.dtype.names:
2465  _recursive_filled(current, mask[name], fill_value[name])
2466  else:
2467  np.copyto(current, fill_value[name], where=mask[name])
